introduction: The Mushaf contains symbols that guide the reciter on where to stop, pause, or continue. These are not part of the Quran itself but were added by scholars to assist recitation.

symbols.description: You MUST stop here. Continuing would change or distort the meaning of the verse.
It is better to stop here. The meaning is complete at this point.
Stopping and continuing are both acceptable. The meaning works either way.
Continuing is better, but stopping is permissible.
Stopping is permitted out of necessity (e.g., running out of breath), but continuing is preferred.
You should NOT stop here. Stopping would break the meaning. Continue to the next natural stopping point.
Two stop marks placed on two nearby phrases — you must stop at ONE of them but NOT both. Stopping at both would break the meaning.
Pause briefly (about 2 beats) without taking a breath, then continue. There are 4 mandatory Saktah positions in the Quran according to Hafs.
It is preferred to stop here, though the meaning connects to what follows.
Stopping is better than continuing, but continuing is still permissible.
Continuing is better than stopping, but stopping is still permissible.

stopping_effects: Tanween becomes silent — the 'n' sound drops when stopping
Qalqalah letters at end receive echoing sound
Madd 'Arid lil-Sukoon may apply (2, 4, or 6 beats)
